PFTBLCTL(8) System Manager's Manual PFTBLCTL(8)

NAME

pftblctl — control the pftbld(8) daemon

SYNOPSIS

pftblctl [-q] [-s socket] command/address [argument ...]

DESCRIPTION

pftblctl acually is a wrapper script facilitating the use of pftbld(8) in verbose pipe mode. It is primarily intended to be used for sending commands to the control socket, but may as well be utilized to forward client data to the corresponding data socket.

The options are as follows:

-q
Quiet mode, generally preventing output on stdout. This flag may be specified multiple times. If specified just once, the command will be sent to the server and pftblctl will silently wait for the conversation to finish. If specified more than once, right after having sent the command to the server pftblctl will return immediately, not awaiting any reply. Please note that, in this case, pftblctl may even return before the command was acually executed on the server.
-s socket
Specifies the socket used to send data to and defaults to /var/run/pftbld.sock.

COMMANDS

On the control socket, the following commands will be accepted:

config option
Runs the specified configuration option. Valid options are:
print
Prints the current configuration to stdout.
reload
Reconfigures pftbld(8) by initiating a reload of its configuration file pftbld.conf(5). Alternative means to achieve the same goal are for example the rcctl(8) utility:

# rcctl reload pftbld

or the pkill(1) command:

# pkill -HUP pftbld
drop [recap] address/network [target]
Deletes the given address/network ahead of schedule from corresponding pf(4) tables and from memory, optionally filtered for the given target. If target is omitted, removal will affect all targets. Since normally every single deletion will be logged, specifying large network ranges may lead to log files getting flooded with deletion entries. This can be avoided by passing the recap keyword which will make sure just a short summary (providing the number of deleted addresses per target and the overall number of dropped client entries) gets written into the log file instead.
dump target
Writes managed addresses and meta-data (number of hits and timestamp of last occurrence) of the specified target to stdout.
expire [recap] address/network [target]
Like the drop command, but just deletes address/network from pf(4) tables while still keeping memorized.
list [address/network] [target] [filter option ...]
Prints a list of memorized client information to stdout. The list will be reversely ordered by expiration/drop date with the next event printed last. Output may be filtered by specifying an IP address/network and/or a target name and may be further narrowed down by specifying the filter keyword followed by at least one option. Valid options are:
active
Matches only clients currently present in a pf(4) table.
addresses
Reduces client information to the IP address and omits any further output.
save target
Writes managed addresses and meta-data (number of hits and timestamp of last occurrence) of the specified target to the corresponding persist path specified in the configuration file pftbld.conf(5), or (if not specified) no action will be performed.
self-exclude [address/network | remove]
Writes address/network into the first location of the global exclude list and is intended to be used for the publicly visible address/network pftbld(8) is running on. If the remove keyword is used instead of an address/network, the current self-exclude will be deleted. If called without parameter, the current self-exclude will be printed to stdout.
status
Prints a status report to stdout.
verbose [level]
Get/Set the verbosity level. If issued without parameter, the current level will be printed to stdout.

FILES

/var/log/pftbld.log
Default log file.
/var/run/pftbld.sock
Default control socket.

EXIT STATUS

pftblctl returns 0 when it was able to successfully send a command to the server and, unless quietened, also successfully read the server's reply, and returns >0 otherwise.

Please note that the pftblctl exit status does not tell anything about the exit status of the command it submitted to the server. In order to gain this information, catching the reply from the server and/or examining the server's log file is the way to go.

EXAMPLES

Here's an example for a status report:

# pftblctl status
Self-exclude: [129.128.5/24]
Verbosity level: 0
Client count:
	target [www]: 249 (7 active)
Next scheduled event:
	[11.22.33.44]:[www]:(2x:50m12s)
		expires from { attackers } in 9m48s,
		on [21/Jul/2020:11:22:56 +0200]

Figuring out how many managed clients are currently present in a pf(4) table may be accomplished like this:

# pftblctl list filter active addresses | wc -l
       7

The next example shows a control command deleting the address 11.22.33.44 for the www target from memory:

# pftblctl drop 11.22.33.44 www
1 client entry dropped.

The corresponding log entry might look like this:

[...] [11.22.33.44]:[www]:(2x:1h3m17s) dropped.

Last but not least, pftblctl may also be used to send client data to the server:

# pftblctl -s /var/www/run/pftbld-www.sock 11.22.33.44 "Test 1"

SEE ALSO

pf(4), pftbld.conf(5), pftbld(8)

AUTHORS

The pftbld(8) program was written by Matthias Pressfreund.
